conclusion: To determine the work done by the gas when it changes from state B to state C, we need to analyze the changes in the internal energy (U) and pressure (p) of the gas during this process.
Initial State (B): Temperature: T_{B}, Pressure: p_{B}, Volume: V_{B}
Final State (C): Temperature: T_{C}, Pressure: p_{C}, Volume: V_{C}
Given that the internal energy U of the ideal gas is related to the temperature T by the equation U = aT, where a is a positive constant.
We can express the internal energy at state B as U_{B} = aT_{B}.
Since the internal energy is also related to the pressure and volume by the equation U = pV.
We can express the internal energy at state C as U_{C} = p_{C}V_{C}.
Given that the volume at state C is 0.5V_{0}.
We can substitute this value into the equation for U_{C}: U_{C} = p_{C} \times 0.5V_{0}.
Since the internal energy at state B is aT_{B}, we can express the internal energy at state C as U_{C} = aT_{B} \times 0.5V_{0}.
The work done by the gas is given by the difference in internal energy between states B and C: W = U_{C} - U_{B}.
Substituting the expressions for U_{C} and U_{B} into this equation: W = (aT_{B} \times 0.5V_{0}) - (aT_{B}).
